Lack enough support: The claim that the ACLU has filed a suit to end prayer from the military completely lacks support as both a Defense Department spokesman and an ACLU spokeswoman have denied its existence.
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that the ACLU is actively working to eliminate prayer from the military, but there is no evidence to support this assumption.
Contradict fact: The claim contradicts the fact that there is no ACLU lawsuit of this kind pending, as confirmed by both the Defense Department spokesman and the ACLU spokeswoman.
Understate: The claim may understate the actual actions of the ACLU regarding defending the rights of all Americans to practice their faith, as mentioned by the ACLU spokeswoman.
Falters at times: The claim falters at times by relying on rumors and misinformation, as indicated by the debunking of similar claims in the past.
Exist alternative explanation: There may be alternative explanations for the actions of the Navy court reprimanding the evangelical Protestant chaplain, such as disobedience of orders or engaging in political protests while in uniform.
